title: Processing arguments by hand
When the command-line syntax for an application is simple, it is reasonable to do the command argument processing entirely in custom code.

inline_content.Text: When the command-line syntax for an application is simple, it is reasonable to do the command argument processing entirely in custom code.

title: In this example, we will present a series of simple case studies. In each case, the code will produce error messages if the arguments are unacceptable, and then call
System.exit(1)
c
to tell the shell that the command has failed. (We will assume in each case that the Java code is invoked using a wrapper whose name is “myapp”.)

inline_content.Text: In this example, we will present a series of simple case studies. In each case, the code will produce error messages if the arguments are unacceptable, and then call
to tell the shell that the command has failed. (We will assume in each case that the Java code is invoked using a wrapper whose name is “myapp”.)

title: A command with no arguments
In this case-study, the command requires no arguments. The code illustrates that
args.length
c
gives us the number of command line arguments.

inline_content.Text: In this case-study, the command requires no arguments. The code illustrates that
gives us the number of command line arguments.

title: A command with two arguments
In this case-study, the command requires at precisely two arguments.

inline_content.Text: In this case-study, the command requires at precisely two arguments.

title: Note that if we neglected to check
args.length
c
, the command would crash if the user ran it with too few command-line arguments.

inline_content.Text: Note that if we neglected to check
, the command would crash if the user ran it with too few command-line arguments.

title: A command with “flag” options and at least one argument

inline_content.Text: A command with “flag” options and at least one argument

title: In this case-study, the command has a couple of (optional) flag options, and requires at least one argument after the options.

inline_content.Text: In this case-study, the command has a couple of (optional) flag options, and requires at least one argument after the options.

title: As you can see, processing the arguments and options gets rather cumbersome if the command syntax is complicated. It is advisable to use a “command line parsing” library; see the other examples.

inline_content.Text: As you can see, processing the arguments and options gets rather cumbersome if the command syntax is complicated. It is advisable to use a “command line parsing” library; see the other examples.
